title: As a Malaysian, can I debut as a KPOP idol? - Quora

response.answer_text: There is actually one person from Malaysia's 2nd biggest state which is Sabah! (the place where I was born)  His full name is Isaac Voo Kai Meng (邬凯名).2. His birthday falls on 12th December 1994 and he was born in Kota Kinabalu, Sabah. He’s also the youngest in his family. 3. He studied at SJK (C) Chung Hwa Likas and SM Lok Yuk, where he was active in volleyball. 4. He became a top 4 finalist in the AlphaBAT audition in Malaysia when they were searching for its 10th member 5. This Sabahan lad actually quickly shot to fame after he participated in an idol survival programme called BOYS24. This programme commenced in August 2016 with 27 participating members who then began their series of concerts. They have reportedly completed 260 concerts since then. That’s impressive! 6. He's in a boy group called IN2IT So can you debut as a kpop idol? Yes but you should never give up and you should learn how to persevere. Remember, you're competing against other people far more “qualified” such as the Koreans, Japanese, Chinese and the Thais. You're a Malaysian, flying overseas to Korea to work as an idol. You have to work harder than everybody else to be recognized. Learn Korean, study their culture and never slack off, since your place might be taken away. If you want to live as an idol just because you want to marry your oppa, but not because of your passion to sing, dance, or to compose then its meaningless. Living as one is hard and you have to prepare mentally and physically for it, especially if you are a Malaysian + came from a big company. You are prone to sasaeng fans, accidents (Wendy broke her pelvis and arms on the 25th of Dec during a rehearsal) and illness (GD was hyperventilating during Bigbang's concert). I'm not trying to scare you but these are the facts we all need to swallow. I am interested in becoming one too since I love dancing and my passion for music is indescribable (now I'm just making music by organising loops. Haven't use those advanced music programmes yet). The pressure from training could motivate me to do harder. The only two things that kinda stop me are money and the lack of bravery. So if you want to go for it, then do your best!

This is coming from a Malaysian (well, a half one) so if you’re Malaysian, apa khabar? As a lot of people answered, there is a Malaysian idol. One. So obviously, it’s possible. Now, if you happen to try to sign into companies who think more about talent and attitude, as opposed to those who care more about looks, you might have a chance—if you’re talented and have a nice attitude. But, if you happen to try to sign into a company that cares more about looks, that’s gonna be a bit tough. Unless, of course, you have Korean features and just overall look Korean. Then again, they’ll know about the hate you could get just for being a foreigner. Which makes it even more tough. It’s possible, but the possibility is really low. Unless of course, you pass for all the above. Don’t lose hope and go get it!

Malaysia’s neighbour Singapore has a kpop girl group Beaunite and Thailand has few kpop idols born and raised there such as BamBam and Lisa. So if Singaporeans and Thais can be idols, I don’t see why Malaysians can’t. Of course it won’t be easy as one will have to undergo years of training and have at least decent visuals, vocals, dance, Korean, etc. Also finding the company they want to train under and then auditioning into the company won’t be easy. Honestly I don’t understand why there have been no kpop idols from Malaysia as there are quite a number of Singers with great vocals and more than decent visuals. Maybe it’s because they want to stay in their homeland with their families? Not too sure. But I won’t be too surprised if a Malaysian born kpop idol appears in the next few years. Hope this answer helps!

I’ve been in Entertainment industry in Korea for some time now and I had lots and lots of people around me asking the similar questions. So here’s some of the tips that I gave . First of all, what we gotta understand here is that Korean entertainment market is not as organized and developed as its size. Most do not hire through official recruiting process, but through personal connections (from one person’s manager to another) However, dont lose hope! Wait for the recruitment post, constantly check out recruiting websites (알바몬 , its the recruiting websites with one of the most foot-traffic in Korea.) the website is not translatable. You can type (entertainment, 엔터테인먼트 (=entertainment in Korean), or 방송국* (meaning broadcasting stations) (You might need someone to help you understand the job description) Broadcasting stations! are great place for you to lay a groundwork to dive into the entertainment industry. Looking for interns such as volunteers for audition tv show that hires worldwidely. You can definitely grow your network there. Being a foreigner with high passion and knowledge in the industry can be a big advantage you have! Have some professional skills in your quiver (such as Accounting or interpretation experience) (and you can get hired as an accountant or interpreter first!) Another way is (if you got nothing) to get a language teaching job near the company you wanna get in or in Seoul, and paying a visit to the companies and sending out cvs personally. (If you want to work in Korea, unless you teaching English for speaking classes, you better know how to speak on an intermediate level) I cannot promise anything, but I might still have some strings i may be able to pull. leave a comment.
